I would more readily believe this if his overall grammar and diction throughout the story was more on the rough side. About the worst thing he does is clip some sentence beginnings, but the rest of his language doesn't indicate that's he uneducated or poor with his grammar. I mean, this would also be more understandable for someone who's like a mercenary and a meathead, but again, we see this man is a collector of artifacts, and one who is also skilled enough with translating ancient texts - which requires a pretty well based understanding in your own spoken and written langauges. Furthermore, he doesn't fall prey to the bad grammar later on, as seen here:

"I am sorry to inform you, Ezreal, that the Guild** has **once again denied your application."

It feels severely out of place, even if it is intentional, because his general grasp on language doesn't indicate that he's bad with his grammar and diction.

In American English, collective nouns can still use both singular and plural verbs, depending on the situation.  People tend to ignore or forget a lot of formal rules for the language, but it's elementary school grammar.

> [{quoted}](name=Ice Weasel X,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=xooGh8ve,comment-id=0002000200000000,timestamp=2018-10-06T05:48:05.792+0000)

It really isn't, to my recollection, and native US speakers extremely rarely use it, and I don't believe I've legitimately seen it - this coming from someone who grew up reading high fantasy novels. It might be some obscure rule in the language, but it's a very dead rule in terms of usage. 
In regards to your previous post about the article you linked, this instance doesn't even follow those rules, because the collective in this sense is acting as a cohesive unit in not liking Ezreal, where your article states that pluralization is used when the individuals within a unit are doing separate things.
Though further research, I've also discovered that if you are indeed invoking this obscurity, it is then considered grammatically incorrect to swap plurality within the same written piece, which would therefore mean that since the first instance is where it's plural, the second instance where it's singular is incorrect.

> Though further research, I've also discovered that if you are indeed invoking this obscurity, it is then considered grammatically incorrect to swap plurality within the same written piece, which would therefore mean that since the first instance is where it's plural, the second instance where it's singular is incorrect.

In the interest of full disclosure, I haven't read the lore to which you're referring, so they may indeed have used it incorrectly.  However, collective nouns having both singular and plural usage is something I was definitely taught in grade school.  I probably had similar reading habits as you since my older sister's a fantasy geek, so I was constantly exposed to a mix of archaic, overly formal, or completely non-historic language in the books she lent me.  It's one of the reasons I remember the topic of collective nouns from school so vividly (the other reason is that the topic was taught in different years).  Something I previously had attributed to style for atmosphere's sake ended up being explained in English class.  "The council agree."  It sounds weird, but it's grammatically sound.

I don't believe there is such a rule prohibiting both singular and plural uses of a collective noun in a single written piece, so long as each instance is individually in agreement with its purpose by restating the noun itself.  For clarity's sake, it may be recommended against, similarly to using the same pronoun several times to refer to multiple different parties (e.g., "Caitlyn shot at Jinx because she tried to kill her every time she saw her."  Is Caitlyn defending herself or is she the instigator?).  Using the collective noun once and then applying both singular and plural versions to it, however, does seem wrong.

* "The Dallas Cowboys is an NFL team.  The Dallas Cowboys are all men."  This may cause a double-take, but I don't really think it's against the rules.  In this case, the proper noun uses a plural form, but can still be taken as a singular entity.
* "The Dallas Cowboys is an NFL team.  They are all men."  This definitely seems problematic, as it is inconsistent and does not "redefine/reinitialize" the term's scope.
I see what you're going for here, and understand the difficulties. Writing the way a character speaks is always a fine line, since it depends on the audience to understand it as such.
British vs American English.

I think it depends on how unified the subject is - does it refer to a single well-organized entity, or a group of entities loosely working together?  I’d say a “guild” is typically the latter.

Or it could have something to do with proper nouns only.

Possibly both.

> [{quoted}](name=Alzon,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=xooGh8ve,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2018-10-05T17:53:19.551+0000)
>
> I think it depends on how unified the subject is - does it refer to a single well-organized entity, or a group of entities loosely working together?  I’d say a “guild” is typically the latter.
> 
> Or it could have something to do with proper nouns only.
> 
> Possibly both.

Guild is a singular noun. A guild is a collective of individuals - when you're discussing the guild, you're talking about the collective as a single unit, not as their components. 
So the **guild** _IS_ angry with you. The guild **members** _ARE_ angry with you.
There are very very few words in the English language that function as their singular and plural forms, and "guild" is not one of them. 
Proper nouns still follow these same rules, especially in regards to groups with a name. 
The **Order of the Banana** is upset with you. The **members** of the Order of the Banana are upset with you.

> [{quoted}](name=Oleandervine,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=xooGh8ve,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2018-10-05T18:01:07.292+0000)

> So the **guild** _IS_ angry with you. The guild **members** _ARE_ angry with you.
> There are very very few words in the English language that function as their singular and plural forms, and "guild" is not one of them. 
> Proper nouns still follow these same rules, especially in regards to groups with a name. 
> The **Order of the Banana** is upset with you. The **members** of the Order of the Banana are upset with you.

Well, sort of.  You've mentioned the key word: collective.  A collective noun _can_ switch between singular and plural verbs, depending on context.  Which is correct relies on whether the individuals within the collective are acting separately, but the collective noun can still be used in both cases.  There aren't specific words which have this ability.  It's a regular attribute of collective nouns.

This is something I remember from grade school English lessons, because it's an odd piece of grammar that often sounds odd to many people.

Here's an article about the subject: http://learnersdictionary.com/qa/Collective-Nouns-and-Verb-Agreement
